vectorData.altText: White matter tracts are stippled and nuclei are solid pink. The long tracts that you are familiar with have been colour coded for you. Answer the questions to identify the cranial nerve nuclei.

Which cranial nerve emerges from the interpeduncular fossa? Think, then click!      Trace the nerve into the brainstem to find its nucleus.
What is the function of this nerve / nucleus?

CN III innervates all extraocular eye muscles except the superior oblique, which functions to depress the eye (SO innervated by CN IV = “SO4”), and lateral rectus, which functions to abduct the eye (LR innervated by CN VI = “LR6”). All others are innervated by CN III (All Others innervated by CN II = “AO3”).
So, the mnemonic is: SO4, LR6, AO3
In addition, CN III innervates the levator palpebrae superioris a voluntary muscle that  opens the eye and delivers parasympathetics to the constrictor pupillae, which makes the pupil small.
Lesion of the oculomotor nerve or nucleus causes the eye to position itself “down and out” because the SO and LR are unopposed, with a droopy eyelid (paralysis of levator palpebrae superioris) and an enlarged pupil (unopposed sympathetics). Does this classic presentation of an “oculomotor nerve palsy” make sense?

Which cranial nerve emerges  from the dorsal aspect of the midbrain? Think, then click!      Trace the nerve into the brainstem to find its nucleus.
What is the function of this nerve / nucleus?
It innervates the superior oblique muscle. Lesion of CN IV causes difficulty in adducting the eye, particularly when looking downward, like when going down a flight of stairs.

Some things you just need to be told!
is the substantia nigra, one of the basal ganglia. it is involved in Parkinson’s Disease.
is the red nucleus, source of the rubrospinal tract
is the decussation of the superior cerebellar peduncles. More about that next week when you learn about the cerebellum.
